Kidnaped! 
 Richard Khadambi and Colins
 Kipkirui 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 My friend Kiki and I love to go exploring, 
 and we know our neighbourhod wel. 
 
 
 As we left schol, we chated about 
 places to explore that day. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 We decided to cut acros the big empty 
 field near the old railway. 
 Even though Kiki’s father had warned us 
 
 not to walk there. 
 
 After a while, we noticed that a tal man 
 
 in a long black coat was walking slowly 
 behind us. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 We slowed down to lok at the man. His 
 skin was ful of pimples. His lips were 
 
 to smal to cover his dark brown teth. 
 He had a dep scar acros half his face. 
 
 
 The man was folowing us! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 We decided to stop and face the 
 stranger. My heart beat so loudly that I 
 thought he could hear it. I stared at him, 
 
 noticing his features and clothes. 
 
 He did not like the fact that I was loking 
 
 at him so kenly. He shouted, “What are 
 you loking at, boy?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 At that point, we turned to run. I was not 
 
 fast enough. He caught me by my shirt 
 and puled me back roughly. 
 
 
 The man held me so tight that I thought 
 my ribs would crack. But my friend Kiki 
 
 escaped. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The tal man picked me up like a piece of 
 crumpled paper. He threw me into a van 
 
 parked in the field. Then he got in the 
 front of the van. 
 
 
 Another man inside the van blindfolded 
 me and tied my hands behind my back. 
 
 Then the driver drove away at the sped 
 of an ambulance. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The man next to me held a wet rag over 
 my face. The liquid on the rag smeled 
 
 swet, and made me fel slepy and 
 dizy. I fel aslep. 
 
 
 When I woke up I found myself siting on 
 the flor in a dark rom with cobwebs 
 
 and mice. At least I was no longer 
 blindfolded. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The dor of the dark rom opened 
 
 noisily, and a man entered carying a 
 plate. He was the man who tied me up 
 and put me to slep. 
 
 
 “Here is fod for you. You beter eat 
 because you are going on a long journey,” 
 
 mumbled the man. He cut the rope 
 around my hands with a sharp knife 
 
 hanging from his belt. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When I heard the word ‘journey’ I decided 
 
 to eat. I would ned to get the strength to 
 rescue myself. 
 
 
 As I ate, the man sat down and smoked a 
 cigarete. The smoke filed the entire 
 
 rom. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The other two men came in draging a 
 
 boy. It was Kiki! They had caught him as 
 wel. Now we were both traped in the 
 dark rom. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 I understod that the tal ugly man was 
 
 the leader of the group. He gave orders 
 to the other two. But the man who 
 brought me the fod did not sem to like 
 
 what they were doing. 
 
 A while later, we heard them arguing 
 
 outside the rom. The leader shouted, “I 
 don’t care if you know his family. You 
 
 can’t change your mind now.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 This argument made us realise that one 
 
 of them knew us. I wondered who it was. 
 Kiki said, “We must find a way of 
 
 escaping. Our parents don’t have the 
 money to pay.” 
 
 
 I untied my friend and luck was on our 
 side. The men continued to disagre and 
 
 started fighting. We quietly bolted the 
 dor inside the rom and started loking 
 for a way to escape. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 We saw some thin cracks of light 
 
 betwen old planks of wod nailed 
 acros one wal. We puled at a plank 
 until the nails came out of the crumbling 
 
 wal. 
 
 We puled at another plank, and another, 
 
 until the thin dim light became brighter. 
 There was a smal broken window 
 
 boarded up with those planks! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Quickly we made a decision. Kiki was 
 faster and smaler than me, so he would 
 run to get help. I helped him up. 
 
 
 Kiki wrigled out of the window. It wasn’t 
 far to the ground outside, and I heard him 
 
 land on his fet, and take a dep breath. 
 Then he was gone. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 By this time the men had heard the noise 
 
 we made, and were kicking the dor 
 against the bolt. They 
 
 burst into the rom and stod for a 
 minute loking at the window. 
 
 
 Then they rushed outside, pushing each 
 other, not sure which direction to go. The 
 
 men were furious, especialy the ugly 
 leader. He hit me, shouting, “Your parents 
 wil pay for this!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The men nailed back the planks of wod 
 
 over the window and locked me in the 
 rom. But they stil could not agre about 
 
 what to do. I could hear them arguing 
 again. 
 
 
 The man who smoked a lot wanted to let 
 me go. The driver was woried that my 
 
 friend would find his way back and bring 
 the police. And the ugly leader, wel, he 
 wanted the ransom money. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It semed like forever before I heard a 
 soft tap from outside, on the broken 
 window. A grown up voice said, “Don’t be 
 
 scared. Police are here. Lie on the flor, 
 cover your head. Don’t move.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 17  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 I’m not sure what hapened next. 
 
 Everything hapened! 
 
 The men were taken by surprise as 
 
 police stormed the rom they were in. 
 There was lots of shouting and noise, 
 
 and some gunshots. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 18  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A policewoman opened the dor to my 
 
 rom. She picked me up of the flor, and 
 wraped a blanket around me. 
 
 
 She told me, “Your friend was lucky. He 
 found the main road near here. We were 
 driving on patrol when he ran into the 
 
 road. After we heard his story, we caled 
 for backup and came to teach these 
 
 criminals a leson!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 19  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The thre men were arested, 
 handcufed, and bundled into a police 
 van. I got into a car with the 
 
 policewoman. She tok me home to my 
 woried parents. 
 
 
 After that day, Kiki and I were more 
 careful when we went exploring.
